subsc: Health,Central government administration,Sanitation,Primary education,Other social services
trustfund:
TF034002-NICARAGUA - SOCIAL INVESTMENT FUNDS,TF022914-PHRD-SOCIAL SECTOR REHABILITATION,TF029201-PHRD-SECOND SOCIAL INVESTMENT
            FUND PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. The positive lessons learned are: 1) Social
            Investment Emergency Fund's (FISE's) institutional
            capacity made it possible to effect a systematic change,
            which was facilitated by the close collaboration of FISE and
            major donors. 2) Highly experienced senior management and
            technical staff and their continuity have been absolutely
            critical to the project's success. 3) The increasing
            complexity of social investment funds requires substantial
            International Development Association supervision. 4) The
            sustainability of investments is directly linked to
            beneficiary participation. The negative lessons learned are:
            a) FISE's operational efficiency is dependent upon the
            abilities of ministries and government agencies. b) Social
            investment funds operate in a political environment which
            involves pressures of a political nature on decision-making
            that may be inescapable. c) The lack of effective
            coordination at all levels had a negative impact on
            implementation performance. d) The organizational
            difficulties in the water supply and sanitation sector were
            underestimated. e) The depreciation of the special drawing
            rights and consequent reduction in funding for FISE's
            investment program covered by the credit taught FISE that
            multiple currency credits can be risky.
